subject: Re: JUnit 3.8.1: Maximum number of testXXX() methods
msgSnippet: I can t recreate it with a stripped down test. My test class extends a generic test class that our project group uses. The generic test class imports many
messageBody:
I can't recreate it with a stripped down test. My test class extends a
generic test class that our project group uses. The generic test class
imports many packages, etc.

I'll just have to live with it for now until I get more time to pursue
this issue.

Thanks.

--- In junit@y..., "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@s...> wrote:
> This is very odd. Could you post the test - especially if you can
recreate
> the problem with the insides of the test methods stripped out for
brevity.
>
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> Mike Silverstein
> SilverMark, Inc.
> The object testing company
> http://www.javatesting.com
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: eyl2k [mailto:eyl2k@y...]
> > Sent: Friday, November 01, 2002 5:18 PM
> > To: junit@y...
> > Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit 3.8.1: Maximum number of testXXX() methods
> >
> >
> > My interim workaround is to change all the names of the testXXX()
> > methods to xtestXXX() and then call each one manually from testAll().
> >
> >
> > --- In junit@y..., "eyl2k" <eyl2k@y...> wrote:
> > > MyTestCase with 5 testXXX() methods runs as expected. When I added a
> > > sixth testXXX() method, I get the following error message:
> > > [java] java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError:
> > > sun/reflect/ConstructorAccessorImpl
> > >
> > > When I comment out one of the original testXXX() methods, everything
> > > runs as expected, so the 6th testXXX() method I added is fine.
> > >
> > > I checked the FAQ but couldn't find this issue discussed.
> > >
> > > Thanks for any information.
> >
> >
